evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t0_prelim dataset withstands alternative interpretations and contradicting evidence, maintaining its validity as a root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t0_prelim scenario, including timing, involved personnel, and context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t0_prelim dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If mechanical or environmental factors fully explained the event without communication issues

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) documents crew communication and coordination during pushback, including a trainee stopping and handing over to the instructor, and the aircraft overrunning the tug release point, supporting observable communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication failure or other factors

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t0_prelim scenario, including timing, involved personnel, and context.

assumptions: That the overrun beyond the TRP with engine idle and collision indicates a coordination failure rather than procedural deviation or mechanical fault.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the overrun, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as cause.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t0_prelim dataset withstands alternative interpretations and contradicting evidence, maintaining its validity as a root cause.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication and coordination among crew and tug operators, with a breakdown leading to the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, supporting communication/coordination breakdown as a root cause. Discriminators favor R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN over mechanical failure and marking deficiency, but procedural deviation is favored over communication breakdown by some evidence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown due to overlapping behaviors
